question.questionText: Anna spilled half of her cup of water on the kitchen floor. The other half was still in the cup. When she came back hours later, all of the water on the floor had evaporated but most of the water in the cup was still there. (Anna knew that no one had wiped up the water on the floor.) Explain to Anna why the water on the floor had all evaporated but most of the water in the cup had not.

referenceAnswers.referenceAnswer: The water on the floor had a much larger surface area. The water in the cup had a much smaller surface area.

studentAnswers.studentAnswer: Because the water on the floor had more room to evaporate and in the cup it only had a little bit of room.
The water on the floor had a bigger space, more open, to evaporate and the cup had smaller space, less space, to evaporate.
The wider the surface the faster evaporation the skinnier the surface the less evaporation.
The water evaporated at it was in the air.
It all evaporated because the water on the floor was wider and had more area while the cup full of water did not have as much area and the more area you have the easier it is to evaporate.

Well Anna, in science, I learned that when water is in a more open area, then water evaporates faster. So, since tile and floor do not have any boundaries or wall covering the outside, the water on the floor evaporated faster, but since the water in the cup has boundaries, the water in the cup did not evaporate as fast.

Because the more the water is exposed the faster it will evaporate.
